idk if we’ll even xmas in our place
we’ll probs put a santa hat on our droid

text: <@U08GFT5V5> btw, how were you inputting japanese characters the other day?
There is a keyboard for it
In Chinese it's called a pinyin keyboard
<@U08GFT5V5> ah, you were using your phone
The phone and of keyboards are identical
The technical term is ime input
You essentially type out what you are trying to produce based on phonetic sounds
And select the correct option with the number keys
that's sort of what I expected

text: That moment when you can finally get the whole new deployment done on production: <https://i.imgur.com/EzcKNIV.png>
So the hotel I'm in has such good 4G+ reception i can max out my download speed of 150mbit/s
Have any interest in annotation processing?
<@U0ESBF4AV> heh, the second word threw me off
word as in the english sense :stuck_out_tongue:
I would've called that the second syllable, I guess
おやすみ is like casual word
Hahaha, actually that's the best way to learn language :stuck_out_tongue:
written characters roughly translate to words
hiragana have only been presented as sounds to me
not every word has a meaning dude
you have "no" the sound and "no" the word (romanized as iie)
When approaching east asian languages, throw everything you think you understand about language out the window
best way to approach it from my experience is with a clean slate
trying to equivocate will only cause you issues
best tip I've received so far is that every syllable is pronounced with the same duration
made listening a lot better for me
Listen to the flow in anime
Japanese isn’t complicated from a vocal standpoint
The issues there are with grammar
the fact that men and women choose different words despite intending to say the same thing is challenging to grasp
the subject is less important than in English, right?
"he ate food" would sometimes just be "ate food"
and I think it comes at the end when actually used
so "food ate" instead of "he ate food"
Kversta daar nu nekeer geen reet van é
yeah, Dutch is a totally different beast I've yet to attempt learning
If you guys start talking Chinese or whatever it is
for the glory of sunrise land
And for some fucking reason my docker instance isn't running correctly on the test production
it definitely looks more complicated IMO than Japanese
nah… they threw grammar out the window
I now realise why people in China always have the good stuff
even though Japan has two alphabets + kanji
They need 4K displays to read those tiny symbols
<@U053LEHJN> I suspect the evolution is as follows
Japanese was actually a chinese dialect
they shared the same character map
they made their own alphabets to be different
They invented hiragana as a learning tool to teach new speakers
it eventually got merged following a pull request
or yeah I guess it had a practical reason too
then Nintendo invented katakana for Game Boy games
since the fancy hiragana was way too complex to be printed on those low-res screens
Japanese kanji is more difficult than Chinese one
is it the kotlin of language?
Chinese only have one way to read kanji
japanese kanji will change based on the usage
作る = Tsuku - ru, 作成 = Saku - sei
First 作 read as Tsuku, second one read as Saku
行 can be read as hang, xing
it’s not that common, but it does happen
Oh, so my chinese friend lied to me lol
Well again, it’s not that common, but it does happen
it happens a lot in Japanese kanji :disappointed:
<@U08GFT5V5> couldn't that just be like a regional accent/dialect then?
Nah this is not even close
the first case would be like 银行
oh, you meant "where it's used" as in context
then other would be 还行
Yeah, similar to how pronunciation changes based on context in Japanese
no real way to reason it out
you just have to memorize the differences
